items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Glenn VanderZee, PrincipalSUBJECT:James Lick High School PresentationThe Summer Bridge Program at James Lick intends that middle school students transition to high school with clear goals, clarity of action and ownership of their study and school experience.The six week program, an extension of the Cal-SOAP Algebra Academy, is a partnership effort between various agencies designed to provide the unique off-site experiences, college visits, one-on-one transition counseling, four-year and six-week student planning, and Mathematics and Language Arts skill development that jumpstart James Lick students toward graduation and further education.The results of the program clearly compel the site to continue the program and to build on it.  The data surrounding the site and learners like those of James Lick, demand that we focus our efforts on middle to high school transition on skill development inasmuch as we effectively provide a context and purpose for high school study that extends beyond these four years.
items.item_text: James Lick High School Presentation - Dan Moser, Acting Superintendent and Glenn VanderZee, Principal
items.item_text_raw: 9.01 James Lick High School Presentation - Dan Moser, Acting Superintendent and Glenn VanderZee, Principal

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Teresa Marquez, PrincipalSUBJECT:Mt. Pleasant High School PresentationThe mission of Mt. Pleasant High School is to provide an academically challenging, supportive, and safe environment in which each student is encouraged to be personally and socially responsible, self-motivated and a life-long learner.  The MP team joins parents and community to prepare the students to be productive adults. Teachers are at the core of our school’s mission. One of the major school restructuring efforts in the last few years has been the institutionalization of a 30 minute Advisory/Study Hall period. For the last 4 years, the staff at Mt. Pleasant High School has studied student achievement data, attendance trends and the affective needs of our student population. From this self-study, teachers created the Advisory model that the school followed for three years. Last year, after evaluating the Advisory model in place at the time, and discussing the challenges that the staff and students would face this school year, the staff voted to restructure Advisory into a 30 minute Study Hall. Today’s presentation will focus on the impact this new Study Hall model will have on the student’s academic achievement, the alignment of the Study Hall goals with our WASC and Single School Plan goals, and the opportunities for teacher leadership that this self-study process has created.
items.item_text: Mt. Pleasant High School Presentation - Dan Moser, Acting Superintendent and Teresa Marquez, Principal
items.item_text_raw: 9.02 Mt. Pleasant High School Presentation - Dan Moser, Acting Superintendent and Teresa Marquez, Principal

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Robert Ibarra, Coordinator of Professional DevelopmentSUBJECT:Accept the Second Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period Covering April 1, 2009 through June 30, 2009 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)BACKGROUNDAs a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela/CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela/CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from April 1, 2009 through June 30, 2009.  FISCAL IMPACT:None FUNDING SOURCE:Senate Bill 6 (Williams)State Instructional Materials AllocationDistrict Instructional Materials BudgetOther Categorical funds as AppropriateRECOMMENDATION:The administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the second Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering April 1, 2009 through June 30, 2009, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).
items.item_text: Accept the Second Valenzuela/CASHEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period Covering April 1, 2009 through June 30, 2009 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727) - Dan Moser, Acting Superintendent and Robert Ibarra, Coordinator Of Professional Development

The elections will take place at CSBA's Delegate Assembly meeting in San Diego on December 2-3, 2009.   Nominations for Directors-at-Large must be made by a CSBA Board Member and the nominee must be a board member from a CSBA member district or county office of education. items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and FacilitiesSUBJECT:Approve Rate of Pay Increase for Campus Police OfficersSan Jose Police Department has implemented a standard hourly rate for officers for all outside uniform employment (i.e., campus security officers).  The minimum rate per hour is $46.50 for officers and $53.50 for supervisors (Security Coordinators).  In order to comply with San Jose Police Department standards, the rate of pay for campus officers must be increased.  This will allow SJPD to continue to provide the District with campus safety supervision.  We are also requesting an increase in the hourly rate of pay for the District Security Coordinator from $54.00 to $56.00 per hour.FISCAL IMPACT:None due to reduction in hours (from six to five hours daily)FUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the increase for campus police officers hourly rates of pay to meet the San Jose Police Department’s standards.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Hold Public Hearing Approximately at 6:30 p.m. for Gann Spending LimitIn accordance with the California Education Code Section 42123 and 1629, a public hearing is to be held prior to the adoption of Resolution #2009/2010-08 Gann Spending Limit.The Gann amendment limits the growth rate of income for state and local governments including school districts.  Each year, school districts and other agencies affected by the Amendment must calculate their Appropriations Limit for the coming year.  There is no direct relationship between the figures, which appear in the calculations of the Gann Limitation and other 2009/2010 budget data since the calculation deals exclusively with proceeds of taxes.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services SUBJECT:Hold Public Hearing Approximately at 6:45 p.m. for Cellular and Wireless Internet Installations on School SitesThe District has been in discussion with cellular service companies that would like to do "small footprint installations" of repeater equipment on school sites.  The companies assume all the responsibility and liability for installation, maintenance and operation of the equipment.  The installations are designed to be nonintrusive and esthetically acceptable while guaranteeing that it is not hazardous or harmful to living organisms.  Verizon and T-Mobile have approached the district and have already completed public school installations in California and in the local area.The financial benefit to the district is approximately $24,000 annually per installation.  The benefit to the community is improved cellular access.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services SUBJECT:Approve Unaudited Actuals for 2008-2009The 2009-2010 Budget for East Side Union High School District, adopted June 25, 2009 included the Unrestricted General Fund ending fund balance for 2008/09, $6,683,000 including General Reserves of $7,298,000.  Upon closing the booked accounts including actual incomes and expenditures recorded and revised as necessary.  The ending fund balance for 2008/09 improved to $12,990,000 including General Reserves of $7,242,000.  In the 2009-2010 Budget the multi-year projections based on the State's February adopted budget indicated a continued pattern of deficit spending (expenditures in excess of annual income) for the two subsequent fiscal years to a point that the District would not meet reserve requirements in 2011-2012 fiscal year.  A plan to address this trend of deficit spending will need to be addressed for the District’s First Interim Financial Report.The deadline for providing the Unaudited Actual Report to the Santa Clara County Office of Education is September 15, 2009.The Unaudited Ending Balance will be audited and revised, as necessary, through the external fiscal Audit process scheduled to be completed in December, 2009 and submitted to the Board in January, 2010. FISCAL IMPACT:Improvement in Beginning Fund Balance for 2009-2010FUNDING SOURCE:Not ApplicableRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Unaudited Actuals for 2008-2009.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services SUBJECT:Request for One-Time Waivers of Board Policy 5142.1 to Allow for a Fireworks Display at Evergreen Valley High School on October 30, 2009On Behalf Of:Inanna Eshoo - ASB President, Evergreen Valley High SchoolSamantha Feril - ASB Vice President, Evergreen Valley High SchoolMichael Ho - ASB Secretary, Evergreen Valley High SchoolDalena Nguyen - ASB Treasurer, Evergreen Valley High SchoolStudents of Evergreen Valley High School are requesting that the use of fireworks/pyrotechnic display be approved on a one-time basis. This display is for homecoming pre-game celebration.Board Policy 5142.1 Prohibits the following at the school sites and on District facilities: (1) open fires including Bon Fires of any type; (2) pyrotechnics of any type; and (3) explosive devices such as firecrackers. Various schools have requested a one-time waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for the planned fireworks/pyrotechnics display for homecoming celebrations.Administration recommends Board approval of the one-time waiver on the following conditions:This is a one time waiver only.The school and the fireworks and pyrotechnics company provider shall provide copies of all necessary, required and appropriate governmental permits, licenses and approvals no later than one business day before the planned event.The school and the fireworks and pyrotechnics company provider shall provide proof of adequate liability insurance coverage for the event (including but not limited to an endorsement naming the District as an additional insured), to be determined by Administration, to be provided at least one business day before the planned event.The fireworks/pyrotechnics displays shall be staged in a safe area.The school shall obtain adequate security and public fire safety personnel and equipment on site during the scheduled event.No other fireworks of any kind shall be allowed on the school campus.The pyrotechnic companies shall be responsible for any damage to the campus including but not limited to the newly-renovated athletic and activities fields.FUNDING SOURCE:ASB FundsRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve request for one-time waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for a fireworks display at Evergreen Valley High School subject to above conditions and the approval from the San Jose Fire Marshall.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Approve a Five (5) Year Lease/Purchase Agreement with Daimler Truck Finance for the Lease/Purchase of Seven (7) Thomas Built Saf-T-Liner C2 191TS School Busses.The District is requesting authorization from the Board of Trustees to enter into a five (5) year Lease/Purchase Agreement with Daimler Truck Finance for the lease/purchase of seven (7) Thomas Built Saf-T-Liner C2 191TS school busses at 5 annual advance payments in the amount of $117,410.47 concluding with $1 buyout.Description of the Purchase:These are special education busses that are needed because of the shortage of busses in the District to meet the needs of the Special Services Department. The purchase includes adding additional wheelchair capacity to the busses that will allow for variable seating that can go from a minimum of 24 ambulatory/1 wheelchair to up to 6 wheelchairs with approximately 6 ambulatory depending on rail placement. This is accomplished by adding additional wheelchair track stations and adding ambulatory track seats for easy change out based on the wheelchair needs. These busses include front and rear air conditioning for medically fragile students.Reason for the Purchase:Current special needs fleet is inadequate for the number of students needing transportation.   The need for wheelchair capacity has grown this school year with projections showing continued growth in wheelchair students needing transportation. Last year we serviced 47 wheelchair students. This year we currently have Bus Service Requests for 68, with the strong likelihood that the number will grow. We have current capacity for 51 wheelchair students. Contracting out services is expensive.  Scores of students have been transported in past years using contractors, resulting in costs of approximately $750,000 each year. By transporting the students in house the District will save a significant amount of money over our current practice of contracting out and most likely needing to expand those contracted out services.  For example, contracted out transportation for 15 Spectrum Center students cost $265,000 last fiscal year. Without these busses, contracting costs will substantially increase as the District will be forced to use the more expensive option to transport these students.Reducing ride times.  The District’s goal of reducing special need student ride times from approximately 1 hour 45 minutes each way to one hour or less has resulted in an increased need for additional busses and drivers. Current ride times under this new policy have been substantially reduced to well under one hour for most students.Selection Process “Piggyback”:These busses are being purchased using a “piggy-back” bid from Hemet Unified School District.  Hemet’s Bid Number 2009/10-0720 closed on August 6, 2009 and was awarded to Bus West on August 18, 2009 by the Hemet Unified School District Governing Board. The price per Thomas Built Saf-T-Liner C2 191TS school bus is $77,428 including tax. Selection Process “Lease/Purchase Finance Company”:Once the busses were selected, Staff then sought to obtain three (3) financing quotes.  The following are the three (3) quote options:Option #1:	Wells Fargo	Term:				5 years, annual payments	Residual:			$1	Annual Advance Payment	$117,496.97	Annual arrears Payment:	N/A	Rate:				4.20%Option #2:	Key Equipment Finance	Term:				5 years, annual payments	Residual:			$0	Annual Advance Payment	$117,821.32	Annual arrears Payment:	$122,946.55	Rate:				4.35%Option #3:	Daimler Truck Finance	Term:				5 years, annual payments	Residual:			$1	Annual Advance Payment	$117,410.47	Annual arrears Payment:	$122.294.74 Rate:				4.16%Staff is recommending Option #3, as the most cost effective financing arrangement for the seven (7) school busses at the 5 annual advance payments in the amount of $117,410.47 concluding with $1 buyout. FISCAL IMPACT:$587,053.35FUNDING SOURCE:TransportationRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the five (5) year Lease/ Purchase Agreement with Daimler Truck Finance for the Lease/Purchase of seven (7) Thomas Built Saf-T-Line C2 191TS school busses.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and FacilitiesVito Chiala, Principal, W.C. Overfelt High SchoolSUBJECT:Approve Participation for Earth Day Network Project at William C. Overfelt High SchoolOverview:Earth Day Network is a non-profit organization that provides a voluntary Green/Solar program to public schools at no cost.  William C. Overfelt High School has been selected as a school to participate in an Earth Day Network Project.The William C. Overfelt High School and Earth Day Network partnership will be an educational endeavor and a project to enhance W.C. Overfelt High School’s efforts to teach and move towards sustainability.  Specifically, this project will involve volunteers to plant native trees, plants and/or complete habitat restoration on and around the campus for a sustainable landscaping project. It will also include the installation of an Earth Day Network donated, no-cost photovoltaic solar panel system on top of the S & T buildings.  This system will also include an educational monitoring display that includes an individual website where students, teachers, and administrators can utilize the system’s performance via consistent updates for educational benefit.  As a keystone celebration of the installation, there will be a related Earth Fair on October 2, 2009 with local and Bay Area environmental organizations giving educational presentations and information about green opportunities and issues.  Earth Day Network will be responsible for the financial aspects and all of these greening projects will be completed at no cost to William C. Overfelt High School or the school district.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve William C. Overfelt High School’s participation in this very worthwhile endeavor.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Award of Bids:1.  Computer Hardware/Software/Peripherals (Piggyback)2.  Smart Boards (Piggyback)Computer Hardware/Software/Peripherals - PIGGYBACK – CDW-GProject Description:  The ESUHSD will need to procure computer hardware, software and peripherals for the period of July 1, 2009 through December 31, 2009.    Awarding Agency:  CalSAVECalSAVE is sponsored by the Monterey County Office of Education. Launched in late November, 1999, as C-SMART, CalSAVE was originally funded by the California Department of Education (CDE) as one of the initiatives under the Department's Statewide Educational Technology Services (SETS) program. CalSAVE leverages the collective buying power of many schools, using strength in numbers to secure the lowest possible price. There are more than 8,740 K-12 schools in the state of California. When these schools shop individually, through normal education pricing channels, they don’t have significant buying power. By joining forces through CalSAVE, we all save time, money, and aggravation by not having to do an individual competitive solicitation process.    Award Date: Originally awarded in November 2002, Contract No. 519589 and expires on December 31, 2009.  The CDW-G contract is currently being rebid.  FISCAL IMPACT:VariousFUNDING SOURCE:VariousRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees award the use of this piggyback bid (in accordance with Public Contract Code 20118 & 20118.2) from CalSAVE.  The CalSAVE bid will allow for the procurement of computer hardware, software and peripherals for the period of July 1, 2009 through December 31, 2009.  There are no fees to ESUHSD for using this contract.2.  Smart Boards - PIGGYBACK – A+ InteractiveProject Description:  The ESUHSD will need to procure SMART Boards™, and other SMART products that compliment the interactive SMART Boards as deemed necessary.     Awarding Agency: California Department of General Services, Procurement Division, California Multiple Awards Schedules (CMAS) Unit, Contract No. 3-09-70-2688ACMAS offers a wide variety of commodities, non-IT services, and information technology products and services at prices which have been assessed to be fair, reasonable, and competitive.  Small Business participation in the State's procurement processes is critical to the economic health of the State, and essential to the success of the CMAS program. In response to their commitment to increase participation by small businesses, the Department of General Services is waiving the administrative fee for orders to California small businesses certified by the Office of Small Business and DVBE Services (OSDS).  Award Date: July 14, 2009 and expires on February 28, 2013.FISCAL IMPACT:VariousFUNDING SOURCE:VariousRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees award the use of this Multiple Awards Schedules (in accordance with Public Contract Code 10299) from CMAS. The CMAS will allow for the procurement of SMART Technologies products through February 28, 2013.  There are no fees to ESUHSD for using this contract as A+ Interactive is a California Certified Small Business, CA #1055500.
Our adopted rules of Parliamentary Procedure, Robert's Rules, provide for a consent agenda listing several items for approval of the Board by a single motion.  Most of the items listed under the consent agenda have gone through Board subcommittee review and recommendation.  Documentation concerning these items has been provided to all Board members and the public in advance to assure an extensive and thorough review.  Items may be removed from the consent agenda at the request of any board member.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Award the Request for Proposals (RFP), RFP-04-08-09, the Network Infrastructure Upgrade and Telecommunications System, which falls under the District Technology Plan and is a Board approved Measure E ProjectThe following recommendation to the Board of Trustees is for the award of the RFP-04-08-09 for the Network Infrastructure Upgrade and Telecommunications Systems District Wide.  The RFP was released on June 24, 2009 and closed on July 17, 2009.  The RFP was advertised in a local newspaper on June 24, 2009 and July 1, 2009 and sent out to ten (10) known vendors and was available on the East Side Union High School District’s website.  The District received four (4) responsive and responsible proposals.  The evaluation process consisted of reviewing exceptions and compliance with specifications for each proposal.  The proposals were scored in accordance with the scoring matrix in the RFP (see below). RFP Evaluation CriteriaScoringScope of Functionality and Specifications MatrixEvaluation of SolutionAnnual Maintenance CostsCostsVendor Qualifications/Past Relationship with ESUHSD/ ReferencesTotal30%20%10%25%15%100%All of the scores were added together.  However, the RFP was evaluated based on the possibility of splitting the purchasing up amongst several vendors if it was deemed most advantageous for the District. However, after reviewing all aspects of the proposals, the evaluation committee’s determined that is was in the best interest of the District to recommend one vendor and that vendor is AMS.NET, Inc. with the highest score of 95.65%.  Vendor NameScoringAMS.NET,Inc.World Wide TechnologiesAT & TBear Data95.65%87.75%87.05%82.05%FISCAL IMPACT:$9,539,744.59FUNDING SOURCE:Measure ERECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees award of the Request for Proposals (RFP), RFP-04-08-09, the Network Infrastructure Upgrade and Telecommunications System and to enter into a multi-year contract with AMS.NET, Inc.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and FacilitiesSUBJECT:Approve Notice of Completion for Evergreen Valley High School, Building B Kiln Room Project (Rodan Builders, Inc.)Bid #B-13-08-09Pursuant to the contract awarded by the Board of Trustees on January 15, 2009, Rodan Builders, Inc. has furnished all material and finished all labor for the completion of work related to Evergreen Valley High, Building B Kiln Room Project.With the approval of the Board of Trustees, the attached Notice of Completion will be filed with the Santa Clara County Recorder’s Office as required by law.FISCAL IMPACT:$91,500.00FUNDING SOURCE:Capital Facilities FundRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion for Evergreen Valley High School, Building B Kiln Room Project.
